description: From Middle English hot, hat, from Old English hāt, from Proto-Germanic *haitaz (“hot”), from Proto-Indo-European *kay- (“hot; to heat”). Cognate with Scots hate, hait (“hot”), North Frisian hiet (“hot”), Saterland Frisian heet (“hot”), West Frisian hjit (“hot”), Dutch heet (“hot”), Low German het (“hot”), German Low German heet (“hot”), German heiß (“hot”), Danish hed (“hot”), Swedish het (“hot”), Icelandic heitur (“hot”).

definitionGroups.group: Relating to heat and conditions which produce it.

entries.meaning: (of an object) Having or giving off a high temperature.
examples: He forgot that the frying pan was hot and burned his hand.
It is too hot to be outside.
It is hotter in summer than in winter.

entries.meaning: (of a person or animal) Feeling the sensation of heat, especially to the point of discomfort.
examples: I was so hot from being in the sun too long.
Aren't you hot with that thick coat on?

entries.meaning: Feverish.

definitionGroups.group: Active, in use or ready for use (like a bullet or a firing range), turned on (like a microphone or camera).

entries.meaning: (US, not comparable) Electrically charged.
examples: a hot wire

entries.meaning: (informal) Radioactive. [from the 20thc.]
(of a temper) Easily provoked to anger.
examples: Be careful, he has a hot temper and may take it out on you.

entries.meaning: (slang, of a person) Very physically and/or sexually attractive.
examples: That stripper is hot!

entries.meaning: (slang) Sexual or sexy; involving sexual intercourse or sexual excitement.
(slang) Sexually aroused; randy.
examples: Enough foreplay! You’ve gotten me so hot already!

entries.meaning: (slang, with for) Extremely attracted to.
examples: hot for her English teacher

definitionGroups.group: Relating to popularity, quality, or the state of being interesting.

entries.meaning: (informal) Very good, remarkable, exciting. [from the 19thc.]
examples: He's a hot young player, we should give him a trial.

entries.meaning: Popular; in demand.
examples: This new pickup is so hot we can't keep it in stock!

entries.meaning: Of great current interest; provoking current debate or controversy.
examples: a hot topic

entries.meaning: Performing strongly; having repeated successes.
examples: "Keep going! You're hot tonight!" urged Wally.

entries.meaning: Fresh; just released.
examples: A kid can stand in the street and sell newspapers, if the headlines are hot.

entries.meaning: Uncomfortable, difficult to deal with; awkward, dangerous, unpleasant.
(slang) Characterized by police presence or activity.
examples: I wouldn't speed through here if I was you. This area is hot this time of night.

entries.meaning: (slang) Stolen. [from the 20thc.]
examples: hot merchandise

entries.meaning: (slang, of a draft/check) Not covered by funds on account.
examples: I wouldn't trust him. He gave me a hot check last week.

entries.meaning: Very close to finding or guessing something to be found or guessed.
examples: Am I warm yet? — You're hot!
He was hot on her tail.

entries.meaning: (of food) Spicy, pungent, piquant, as some chilis and other spices are.
examples: This kind of chili pepper is way too hot for my taste.

entries.meaning: (of an electric musical instrument) Loud, producing a strong electric signal for the amplifier.
(slang) Used to emphasize the short duration or small quantity of something
examples: He was finished in a hot minute.
I dated him for a hot second.

entries.meaning: (slang, of a vehicle or aircraft) Extremely fast or with great speed.
examples: That plane's coming in hot!
a hot pass

entries.meaning: Hotly, at a high temperature.
Rapidly, quickly.
examples: Whatever happened, braking into the next-to-last hairpin, a blue-sky turn called Cog Cut, Durelle went in too hot.

entries.meaning: (especially in the phrase "come in hot", "go in hot") While shooting, while firing one's weapon(s).

verbs.description: hot (third-person singular simple present hots, present participle hotting, simple past and past participle hotted)

entries.meaning: (with up) To heat; to make or become hot.
(with up) To become lively or exciting.
examples: Turf war's hotting up.
